awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Transparent Beam Steering Antennas Enabled by Graphene Quantum Capacitance Varactors
awd_abstract_narration:
The project intends to create a revolutionary transparent beam-steering antenna technology for use in self-driving vehicles. The project utilizes the artificial impedance surface antenna which is ideally suited for integration into automobile window glass due to its low cost and simple design. The key innovation is to utilize the nanomaterial graphene to create a variable capacitance tuning element that can be integrated directly onto the antenna to enable beam steering while maintaining high performance and transparency. This work will lead to a new fundamental understanding of both the performance limits of graphene varactors as well as the novel antenna design and operation. It will provide new understanding of the frequency limits of graphene devices, and could open the door to new design concepts for transparent, steerable antennas. The project will also advance a technology of vital national importance that has the potential to minimize traffic-related deaths, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, enable unprecedented mobility for vision-impaired individuals, reduce traffic congestion, and improve business productivity. The project will also provide an ideal platform for outreach activities, with the industrial interaction providing a natural means to educate graduate students on the automotive applications of millimeter-wave components. This program will also aid in the incorporation of graphene into the undergraduate electrical engineering curriculum at Minnesota, and provides an excellent example of a cross-disciplinary problem, incorporating aspects of solid-state devices and electromagnetism. In addition, K-12 educational programs will be developed that include graphene-based hands-on activities as well as information about self-driving vehicles and automobile safety.

This project will explore the creation of a transformative technology where graphene variable capacitors (varactors) are directly integrated onto artificial impedance surfaces to enable beam steering antennas operating at millimeter-wave frequencies. The project integrates two technologies that, to date, had not been previously combined: (1) artificial impedance surface antennas which have great potential for low cost and beam steering capabilities due to their simple design and (2) graphene varactors, which provide an elegant method to incorporate tuning elements for beam steering and are also transparent. The research scope and methods include the following aspects. A new fabrication process for short-channel-length graphene varactors will be developed to enable high-speed operation at millimeter-wave frequencies. A process will also be developed to monolithically integrate graphene varactors with artificial impedance surface antennas to create steerable antennas. Finally, transparent antennas will be fabricated and characterized using a metal meshing strategy and their performance will be compared to opaque antennas. The intellectual significance of this project is that it will lead to a fundamental understanding of high-speed graphene device and antenna technology. It will explore the performance limits of graphene varactors at millimeter-wave frequencies, and advance the technology with wider tuning range, higher quality factor, and improved uniformity. A new integrated platform for beam steering antennas at millimeter-wave frequencies will be created, with the potential for enhanced performance compared to conventional approaches and a path toward practical implementation in autonomous vehicles.

por.por_cntn:
The project goal was to develop a revolutionary transparent beam steering antenna technology based upon graphene variable capacitor (varactor) tuning elements. Graphene varactors are an enabling technology for this application because they can be integrated directly onto the metallic antennas, overcoming a key limitation of flip-chip-bonded elements. This allows nearly full transparency to be achieved while maintaining the capability for high performance. The project had three main goals: (1) to develop a fabrication process for graphene varactors that meet the performance requirements for Ka-band operation, (2) to integrate these elements with antennas and demonstrate tunable transmit/receive capability at Ka-bands, and (3) to integrate both varactors and antennas onto a transparent/flexible platform. Several important advancements were achieved that strongly support the feasibility of this transformative technology. The main achievements are as follows:

In Year 1 of the project, a design for short-channel, high-speed graphene varactors was developed that could achieve a tuning ratio of 2 and quality factor of 4 at 40 GHz. The simulations showed that this performance could be achieved in a relative relaxed varactor gate length of only 0.25 μm.

In Year 2, a fabrication process for the varactors was developed and initial characterization of the devices was performed both under near-dc conditions and at microwave frequencies. In addition, a novel ferroelectric non-volatile varactor concept was developed where (Hf,Zr)O2 was used as the gate dielectric. This concept allowed the varactors to be tuned with tuning ratio of 1.2 without the use of an active bias, an important capability for practical applications. Design simulations further showed that much high tuning ratios are possible with optimization.

In Year 3, extensive progress was made on developing the components needed to realize flexible beam-steering antennas. Simulations were performed on tunable surface-wave waveguide (SWG) antennas. The design utilized 80 rows of impedance elements, with 8 varactor components per row where the periodicity of the tuning element variation determined the emission pattern.  Simulations at 67.7 GHz showed that changing the periodicity from 4 to 8 unit cells scanned the beam angle over a range of 78o. In addition, a fabrication process for graphene varactors on flexible commercial glass substrates was developed and the devices showed reproducible operation with tuning ratio of nearly 1.5.

In Year 4, further refinement of the antenna design was performed using more realistic conditions. where the effect of varactor tuning ratio was studied. The results showed that no substantial change in the beam steering is observed was the tuning ratios was decreased from 7.33 to 1.5. These results suggest that the experimental varactors fabricated in this project could be used for demonstrating beam steering antenna operation. In addition, additional experimental characterization of high-speed graphene varactors was performed, including a design optimization study to determine the effect of contact geometry on device performance. The varactors without overlapping contact and gate metal provided the best overall performance due to reduced parasitic capacitance. The best devices showed quality factor as high as 18.4 at 18 GHz, which corresponds to maximum frequency of operation above 300 GHz. In Year 4, the results were presented at a technical conference and in Year 5, the results were further refined and published in a scientific journal.

The broader impacts of this work were that it provided outstanding training for two graduate students, including one female student, in a wide range of fields, including microwave antenna design and simulation, nanoscale device fabrication, and high-speed characterization. It also allowed the students to present findings at scientific conferences and influenced the scientific community through the resultant journal publication. The work could have substantial commercial impact through the collaboration with HRL.
